section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, sing a song, and introduce vocabulary (climb, paths).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How does the girl get ready for her hike up Hickory Hill?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Ask and answer questions about a text; Share observations about events.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to look at pictures and tell what the people are getting ready to do.
Encourage children to respond in complete sentences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kinds of trees do you see in that book? What time of year is it?
What can you pretend to do outside with a friend?
How can you sort toys with a friend into toys made of wood and toys made of plastic?
Share a story about going on a trip or a long walk.
Draw a picture of things you would see if you went for a hike up a mountain.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word paths? Can you write it?
What materials can you use to make a path for hiking?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder talk and share and introduce vocabulary (plan, climb higher).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Hiking Day.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Talk and share.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Social Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children look at pictures of people working together and say what is happening in the picture.
Challenge children to tell how the people are working together.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the people in your book working together?
Pretend you are on a hike up a mountain with your friends.
Name three animals you might see on a hike.
Can you write about something you do together with your family at home?
Can you make a tree you would see on a hike up a mountain?
What letter is at the beginning of the word climb?
Can you build a mountain out of blocks?

Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Lizzy Rockwell. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Ask Questions and introduce vocabulary (trail, woods).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Hiking Day and asking, What do the girl and her parents see as they climb Hickory Hill?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Share observations about events.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children look at pictures and say if the family in the book saw this animal on their hike.
Encourage children to discuss animals that live in the woods.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the trees in those books the same? How are they different?
Pretend you are working with a friend to build a house.
Can you compare the size of two animals? Which is taller? Which weighs more? How do you know?
Can you share a story you wrote with a friend? Can you illustrate it?
Can you imagine a farm with your favorite animals? Can you share that with a friend?
Can you write a letter in a friend’s name? Can you write it in uppercase? Now can you write it in lowercase?
How can you make a vegetable garden with a friend using blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Hiking Day by Anne Rockwell, illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. Text copyright © 2018 by Anne Rockwell. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Lizzy Rockwell. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: We Have Soup!

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background about working together and introduce vocabulary words (soup, peas).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts We Have Soup! and Hiking Day.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s Concept Question, What can we do better together?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Economics: Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and shelter.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children differentiate between vegetables that grow above and below the ground.
Help children explore the growing season of crops.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find examples of people working together in your book?
Pretend you are picking corn. Now you’re pulling onions out of the ground.
Compare how two vegetables are the same and different.
Which vegetables would you want in a soup? Can you write about it?
Can you draw a picture of a delicious bowl of soup that you might make?
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the word vegetables?
Can you build a vegetable stand where you can sell vegetables?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Hiking Day by Anne Rockwell, illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. Text copyright © 2018 by Anne Rockwell. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Lizzy Rockwell. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out scenes from Hiking Day and to introduce vocabulary words (covered, leaps).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Hiking Day and asking, What happens when they reach the top of Hickory Hill?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of text read aloud.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Try a new approach or new tasks; Talk and share.
Write uppercase and lowercase letters.
Share and celebrate written products; Independently write letters to make words or word parts.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What are three things that we can do better with a friend?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Tell a story to a friend about trying to do something new.
Pretend you are climbing a tall mountain.
Can you work together to leap from a starting point and measure how far you jump?
Can you create a story about a friendly toad?
Can you imagine something that you’d like to do that you never did before? What would it be?
What is the letter at the beginning of the word covered?
How would you build a home for one of the animals in the book? What materials would you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Hiking Day by Anne Rockwell, illustrated by Lizzy Rockwell. Text copyright © 2018 by Anne Rockwell. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Lizzy Rockwell. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than used.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Talk and share.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Explore geography tools and resources.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Talk and share.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
Independently use letters to make words or parts of words.
